title: Didier Deschamps delivers update on Hugo Lloris after injury against Brighton
text:
Hugo Lloris had to be stretchered off early on in Tottenham’s defeat to Brighton at the weekend (Picture: AFP)

France manager Didier Deschamps expects his captain Hugo Lloris to be sidelined until next year following his horror injury during Tottenham’s 3-0 defeat to Brighton on Saturday.

The 32-year-old dislocated his elbow just two minutes into the game at the Amex after falling awkwardly into his own net having parried a cross into Neal Maupay’s path to score.

Lloris was clearly in agony as he lay on the turf and he had to receive medical treatment – which included receiving oxygen – for over five minutes before being stretchered off.

Lloris had to receive medical treatment for several minutes after suffering the injury against Brighton (Picture: Getty)

Mauricio Pochettino suggested post-match that it will be a while before Lloris returns, saying: ‘The news is not good from the hospital, but we need to wait, through the website they are going to explain the situation properly.

‘But of course everyone saw on the pitch when he landed, it was not a good situation and the news is not so good.’

Deschamps, though, has gone a step further than Pochettino by effectively ruling Lloris out of France’s final four Euro 2020 qualifiers this month and in November.

‘It is difficult to say exactly how long he will not be available,’ said Deschamps ahead of France’s games against Iceland and Turkey next week.

‘What matters to us right now is that he will not be with us for this round of games or for the next.’

He added: ‘Almost certainly, he won’t be back on the pitch in 2019.’

Lloris’ injury compounded a miserable afternoon for Spurs as they were well-beaten by Brighton just four days after being humiliated by Bayern Munich in the Champions League.

Mauricio Pochettino insists he is not worried about his Spurs future (Picture: Getty)

Argentine goalkeeper Paulo Gazzaniga replaced Lloris in Saturday’s game and now appears set for a lengthy run in the side, with the untested Alfie Whiteman providing backup.

A severe injury to his captain is the last thing that Pochettino would have wanted at a time when Spurs are struggling badly for form and results.

Pochettino insists he is unconcerned about rumours over his future, though, saying: ‘No I am not worried, what worries me is life, not football.

‘I don’t want you to take it the wrong way, what scares me is life, not football. Football is a game that sometimes you win, sometimes you lose.’
